commit_message:
Implied roles driver and manager

CRD for the rules that allow one role to infer another role.
When listing roles, implied roles are inferred from any explicitly
assigned roles.  A config option controls whether implied roles
are expanded in the auth data associated with tokens.

The list_assignment tests helper is also modified to
allow data driven tests for implied roles, and those new tests
are also included here.

Implied roles are not supported by the LDAP drivers; if you
try and CRD implied roles with an LDAP assignment driver a
NotImplemented is returned.

Co-Authored-By: Henry Nash <henryn@linux.vnet.ibm.com>

Partially implements: blueprint implied-roles
Change-Id: I6a9c23aea4b1f348c6c8c2b9274865806d856b82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/60/264260/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # A set of implied role specifications. In this case, prior role # index 0 implies role index 1, and role 1 implies roles 2 and 3. 'roles': [{'role': 0, 'implied_roles': [1]}, {'role': 1, 'implied_roles': [2, 3]}] def create_implied_roles(self, implied_pattern, test_data): """Create the implied roles specified in the test plan.""" for implied_spec in implied_pattern: # Each implied role specification is a dict of the form: # # {'role': 0, 'implied_roles': list of roles} prior_role = test_data['roles'][implied_spec['role']]['id'] if isinstance(implied_spec['implied_roles'], list): for this_role in implied_spec['implied_roles']: implied_role = test_data['roles'][this_role]['id'] self.role_api.create_implied_role(prior_role, implied_role) else: implied_role = ( test_data['roles'][implied_spec['implied_roles']]['id']) self.role_api.create_implied_role(prior_role, implied_role) if 'implied_roles' in test_plan: self.create_implied_roles(test_plan['implied_roles'], test_data)class ImpliedRoleTests(AssignmentTestHelperMixin): def test_role_assignments_simple_tree_of_implied_roles(self): test_plan = { 'entities': {'domains': {'users': 1, 'projects': 1}, 'roles': 4}, # Two level tree of implied roles 'implied_roles': [{'role': 0, 'implied_roles': [1]}, {'role': 1, 'implied_roles': [2, 3]}], 'assignments': [{'user': 0, 'role': 0, 'project': 0}], 'tests': [ # List all direct assignments for user[0], this should just # show the one top level role assignment {'params': {'user': 0}, 'results': [{'user': 0, 'role': 0, 'project': 0}]}, # Now the effective ones - so the implied roles should be # expanded out {'params': {'user': 0, 'effective': True}, 'results': [{'user': 0, 'role': 0, 'project': 0}, {'user': 0, 'role': 1, 'project': 0, 'indirect': {'role': 0}}, {'user': 0, 'role': 2, 'project': 0, 'indirect': {'role': 1}}, {'user': 0, 'role': 3, 'project': 0, 'indirect': {'role': 1}}]}, ] } self.execute_assignment_plan(test_plan) def test_role_assignments_directed_graph_of_implied_roles(self): test_plan = { 'entities': {'domains': {'users': 1, 'projects': 1}, 'roles': 6}, # Two level tree of implied roles, where one of the roles at the # bottom is implied by more than one top level role 'implied_roles': [{'role': 0, 'implied_roles': [1, 2]}, {'role': 1, 'implied_roles': [3, 4]}, {'role': 5, 'implied_roles': [4]}], # The use gets both top level roles 'assignments': [{'user': 0, 'role': 0, 'project': 0}, {'user': 0, 'role': 5, 'project': 0}], 'tests': [ # The implied roles should be expanded out and there should be # two entries for the role that had two different prior roles. {'params': {'user': 0, 'effective': True}, 'results': [{'user': 0, 'role': 0, 'project': 0}, {'user': 0, 'role': 5, 'project': 0}, {'user': 0, 'role': 1, 'project': 0, 'indirect': {'role': 0}}, {'user': 0, 'role': 2, 'project': 0, 'indirect': {'role': 0}}, {'user': 0, 'role': 3, 'project': 0, 'indirect': {'role': 1}}, {'user': 0, 'role': 4, 'project': 0, 'indirect': {'role': 1}}, {'user': 0, 'role': 4, 'project': 0, 'indirect': {'role': 5}}]}, ] } self.execute_assignment_plan(test_plan) def test_role_assignments_implied_roles_filtered_by_role(self): test_plan = { 'entities': {'domains': {'users': 1, 'projects': 2}, 'roles': 4}, # Two level tree of implied roles 'implied_roles': [{'role': 0, 'implied_roles': [1]}, {'role': 1, 'implied_roles': [2, 3]}], 'assignments': [{'user': 0, 'role': 0, 'project': 0}, {'user': 0, 'role': 3, 'project': 1}], 'tests': [ # List effective roles filtering by one of the implied roles, # showing that the filter was implied post expansion of # implied roles (and that non impled roles are included in # the filter {'params': {'role': 3, 'effective': True}, 'results': [{'user': 0, 'role': 3, 'project': 0, 'indirect': {'role': 1}}, {'user': 0, 'role': 3, 'project': 1}]}, ] } self.execute_assignment_plan(test_plan)

commit_message:
Allow monitor plugins to set own metric object

The values reported by a monitor depends on type of value which
will not be uniform for all the monitors. For example, the memory
bandwidth monitor will return a dict of ints while the cpu monitor
returns a normal int value. The monitor metric objects offer
different fields to be set depending on the monitor in question.

This patchset allows the monitors to decide what metric field
it would like to populate as over a general implementation of
creating the monitor metric object inside the base module.

Related to blueprint memory-bw

Change-Id: Id5637f16ee3073a8b268c778b9f91f9f0ca309b2
Co-Authored-By: Ahilan Rajadeva <rajadeva@us.ibm.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/00/252800/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import objects metric_object = objects.MonitorMetric() self.populate_metric_object(name, metric_object) metrics.append(metric_object) def populate_metric_object(self, name, metric_object): metric_object.name = name metric_object.value = self._data[name] metric_object.timestamp = self._data['timestamp'] metric_object.source = self.source

commit_message:
Add microversion to allow uuid in server show response data

This commit add uuid into server show <server-id> response
data with microversions.

This commit also create an uuid when a new security-groups
is created. For the security-groups created before, the uuid
field stays to be None.

APIImpact

commit_message:
Cells: Add cells filter RamByInstanceTypeFilter

We should not send builds to cells that are reporting no free space.

Implements: blueprint cells-ram-filter

Change-Id: I1efe863ac293e698cec9df7c73ab7da740d2ddfc

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Rackspace Hosting # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ When a cell is full, don't send builds there. """ from nova.cells import filters class RamByInstanceTypeFilter(filters.BaseCellFilter): """Filter cells by instance_type requested.""" def filter_all(self, cells, filter_properties): """Use the 'ram_free' for a particular instance_type advertised from a child cell's capacity to decide if there is room in each cell. """ request_spec = filter_properties['request_spec'] instance_type = request_spec['instance_type'] memory_needed = instance_type['memory_mb'] result = [] for cell in cells: ram_free = cell.capacities.get('ram_free', {}) units_by_mb = ram_free.get('units_by_mb', {}) units_free = units_by_mb.get(str(memory_needed), 0) if units_free > 0: result.append(cell) return result

commit_message:
Implements Blueprint: Add Cinder Volume Type in BlockDeviceConfig when booting

We always create the instance by using block-device option for san storage.
So We need the volume type setting function on creating because of a variety
of qos. (In vda).

The usage is as follows.

nova boot <display_name> --flavor <flavor_id> --block-device id=<image_id>,
source=image,dest=volume,device=vda,size=10,bootindex=0,shutdown=remove,
volume_type=high_iops

1. get volume_type when creating instance
2. store information in bdm
3. passed as an volume_type argument, when creating a cinder volume.

Change-Id: I43b22b9b5e06a14a63a7f6a32eb1bb1ac80d6249
Implements: blueprint add-volume-type-in-blockdeviceconfig

commit_message:
Refactor os-services unit tests

- Replace duplicate tests in v21 test class with appropriate ones in v2
   Unit tests for detailed and non-detailed service listing/filtering
  in version 2.1 are identical, as when the endpoint got lifted to the
  new API version, features that were optional became fixed and these
  attributes are always returned. To keep the coverage in the old
  version two cases are added for the two toggle-able attributes.
  Filtering and detailed listing still covered with the inherited test
  cases.
- Rearrange parameters in asserts, so unit test failure printouts
  correctly show reference and test results

Change-Id: I82a100cddf1a745bde457b17102682bd42e4608b
Related-Bug: #1217026

commit_message:
Adding IPv6 static routes and static routes template

When using IPv6 and interface configuration injection
we need to include IPv6 routes. This commit also
includes a working interfaces template for static
routes, which includes IPv4 and IPv6.

To use the provided template, set
'injected_network_template' to
'nova/virt/interfaces-static-routes.template' in
nova.conf.

Implements blueprint interfaces-template-routes
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ia5014884de82253156ebdaf4dbf9990cc358a5d2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/187012/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add support for provider networks in network_data.json

A provider network is a virtual network administratively created to
map to a specific physical network in the data center, typically to
enable direct access to non-OpenStack resources on that network.
Tenants can be given access to provider networks. These are typically
VLANs and GRE tunnels. These provider networks are particularly
useful for bare metal instances.

network_data.json will represent this information so these networks can
be configured automatically by cloud-init and other similar systems.
Cloud-init will be written so that the networkss are only configured
as necessary, probably by looking at the NIC 'type' field to determine
if the NIC is a physical NIC. Virtual instances using OVS and similar
virtual switches will likely not need the segmentation tagging to be added.

Partial-Implements: blueprint metadata-service-network-info
Change-Id: Iee14a29eb1a77597848e86d6e59c078a0899d9c7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/03/152703/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Create a VLAN link from this network if it exists if network.get('meta', {}).get('vlan_id'): vlan = _create_vlan_link(vif, ifc_num, link['id']) if vlan: # Set network to point to VLAN if it exists, otherwise, # directly to NIC links.append(vlan) link = vlan def _create_vlan_link(vif, vlan_num, link): """Creates VLAN link with the same representation as a VIF or physical NIC. :param vif: Neutron VIF :param vlan_num: An int representing the VLAN ID :param link: The VIF or physical NIC the VLAN is attached to """ network = vif['network'] return { 'id': 'vlan%d' % vlan_num, 'type': 'vlan', 'vlan_link': link, 'vlan_id': network['meta'].get('vlan_id'), 'ethernet_mac_address': vif.get('address'), }

commit_message:
Map physical ports to networks.

- Support hints on mappings between physical network ports and networks.
- Ensure Ironic physical interfaces are tagged with the appropriate virtual interface UUIDs.

Change-Id: I3507e8b44d267791eb548b70153af5ade3f48d5a
Closes-Bug: 1405131

commit_message:
libvirt: Add post_connection_terminated

When multiple iSCSI connections are terminated
it is very likely to happen that not all
iSCSI devices and multipath devices are deleted
on the host (where nova-compute is running).
This bugfix adds the possibility to call
post_connection_terminated to the libvirt driver
which can be called after terminate_connection
is called. In the case of iSCSI it will a second
time remove the iSCSI and multipath devices.

Co-Authored-By: Pavel Kholkin <pkholkin@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Sergey Nikitin <snikitin@mirantis.com>

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1336683

Change-Id: I817214749fdb0da8d577ebd89ebdde4f670006ed

deleted_lines: self._terminate_volume_connections(context, instance, bdms) self._terminate_volume_connections(context, instance, bdms) def _terminate_volume_connections(self, context, instance, bdms): connection_info = jsonutils.loads(bdm.connection_info) # NOTE(vish): We currently don't use the serial when disconnecting, # but added for completeness in case we ever do. if connection_info and 'serial' not in connection_info: connection_info['serial'] = volume_id

commit_message:
libvirt: Allow CoW cloning of ISO images on RBD.

Avoid unnecessary downloading of ISO image from Glance when Glance
also uses Ceph/RBD.

Change-Id: I8fb5131839563bba61f7e65091a9e71088ed8e37

commit_message:
Move more qemu calls into virt.images

I'd like to move calls to qemu into a central place because it will
make it easier to work around the vagaries of qemu in a consistent
manner.

Change-Id: I4a7ae10e2bd1d1c72262a9115021eef5b6fcd458

commit_message:
Add uuid into SecurityGroup object

Currently, there is no restriction for this field, and it could
be nullable. We could add additional restriction for it in the
furture.

Also, this commit updates some obj_relationships mapping and
fingerprint.

Related to blueprint add-id-to-security-groups-for-server-show

Change-Id: I841871a63db798541547961626af9cdea963e4de

commit_message:
WIP: Replace service groups with the tooz groups

These changes adds a new tooz driver to manage service
group. Tooz(a new oslo library) will provide same
functionality as the exsisting service group drivers
in place using through tooz's own group membership
abstraction. Firstly introduce the tooz driver and use
it the same way as other drivers are being used. Next
step would be to propose the replacement startegy as we
want to support exsisting drivers alongwith the migration to
tooz.

Change-Id: Id7fe9370756b58a375b4d0286c22502a77ec80ab
Implements: blueprint tooz-for-service-groups

commit_message:
DNM Cells: Provide example request flows for v2

This updates the devref with a high level walkthrough of how some
requests will work in the world of cells v2.  It will be a useful
reference to point to for explaining how specs fit into the larger
picture.  It is also a reference to specs that are in progress and
points out areas that don't yet have specs.

It is not intended to merge, just be a place of discussion and
bookkeeping.

Change-Id: I25a222a231d5932a187d45eafce78c28c6134618
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/09/190209/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Boot request flow ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This is an example trace of what a boot request will look like in order to describe the target we're aiming at: * The API receives a request to boot an instance, with some parameters like image and flavor. * If standard validation checks pass the API is expected to respond with an instance. However, we don't know which cell the instance will be in so we can't create an instance record yet. The information needed to schedule the instance will be stored as a persisted RequestSpec object, and the additional information needed to return an instance via the API will be stored as a persisted BuildRequest object. The boot request will then be sent to the conductor so that the API can respond to the client. ** https://review.openstack.org/#/c/176078/ ** https://review.openstack.org/#/c/169901/ * The conductor will call the scheduler which will return a (host, node) tuple as it currently does. The conductor will use the host_mapping and cell_mapping table to get connection details for the cell which contains that host. ** https://review.openstack.org/#/c/182715/ * The conductor will create the instance record in the cell database, and then pass the boot request to the cell message queue to be picked up by its local conductor. ** Need a spec * The local conductor will boot the instance with very little change from how it currently works. The primary difference is that it will not need to call the scheduler the first time through since a host has already been chosen. ** Need a spec/blueprint There are some assumptions being made here. One big one is that the data necessary for initial API validation is available at the API level. This requires some tables to be moved from the cell database into the api database. The `Global (API-level) Tables` section above provides some examples. Following on from that there's an assumption that everything that will need to be referenced later from that api database will be passed down with the boot request, and persisted if necessary. For example flavor data is attached to the instance object being passed around and persisted in the instance_extra table for later retrieval. This avoids the cells needing to query the api database. ** Need specs for moving tables and migrating data ** Need specs for persisting data that will be needed with the instance later.

commit_message:
Cells: - weight_offset; + selection_multiplier

Weight offsets have been broken since normalization was added. A
selection multiplier allows the operator to directly increase or
decrease the probability of cell selection during scheduling
(including completely disabling a cell by setting multiplier to 0).

UpgradeImpact: WeightOffsetWeigher is deprecated

Change-Id: I25129363c7d3fc7c94001b1fd5f5ba7cca90ea8b

commit_message:
Check for volume size

Added check to ensure volume size
specified by user is greater than
the image size in boot from volume

Change-Id: Id67d0d1d23b6a7040312643d09dcc2b24ea9e562
Closes-Bug: #1465947

commit_message:
Object: Merge db accesses for extra field of instance

This patch puts all extra fields to a local variable extra_db_updates
and add a new provite function to handler db access of update operation.

By doing this it will reduce db access when do instances.save() if there
is any extra fields in instance object.

Change-Id: I3b5dcac6dfe1aa9f367c31a9e7ee206e69fea2cf

commit_message:
Migrate the skip_unless_attr decorator from tempest

This commit migrates the skip_unless_attr from tempest to
tempest-lib.

Change-Id: I6a1e7a411a4b27fa0f9bd533276d5cb4d4759976
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest-lib refs/changes/19/270019/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class TestSkipUnlessAttrDecorator(base.TestCase): def _test_skip_unless_attr(self, attr, expected_to_skip=True): class TestFoo(test.BaseTestCase): expected_attr = not expected_to_skip @decorators.skip_unless_attr(attr) def test_foo(self): pass t = TestFoo('test_foo') if expected_to_skip: self.assertRaises(testtools.TestCase.skipException, t.test_foo()) else: try: t.test_foo() except Exception: raise testtools.TestCase.failureException() def test_skip_attr_does_not_exist(self): self._test_skip_unless_attr('unexpected_attr') def test_skip_attr_false(self): self._test_skip_unless_attr('expected_attr') def test_no_skip_for_attr_exist_and_true(self): self._test_skip_unless_attr('expected_attr', expected_to_skip=False)

commit_message:
switch releasenotes job to branch-git-prep

Use branch-git-prep instead of zuul-git-branch-prep to prepare the local
source repository, since it appears the latter does not work properly in
post jobs, yet.

Change-Id: I8cbcd49ff4bf7234e149985535f394bb686c58c3
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/33/270333/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - branch-git-prep: branch: master

'}]
commit_message:
Remove argparse from requirements

argparse was external in python 2.6 but not anymore, remove it
from requirements.

This should help with pip 8.0 that gets confused in this situation.
Installation of the external argparse is really not needed.

Change-Id: Id8984ef560f0bb3006e360a8cb32fc015a9ccfcf
